item.title: Radio War Nerd EP 443 — France's Wars in Chad, feat. Nathaniel Powell
item.itunes:subtitle: Co-hosts John Dolan & Mark Ames
item.itunes:summary: Guest: Nathaniel Powell Recorded: May 7, 2024 Since 1960, France has intervened in Chad more than in any other of its former colonies, with increasingly disastrous results each time. With France's neo-empire in Africa imploding, we talk to Nathaniel Powell about his book France's Wars in Chad to understand how their interventions failed, and to get a sense of why France is currently facing so much blowback in its former colonies. Buy Nathaniel Powell's book France's Wars in Chad: Military Intervention and Decolonization in Africa. Follow Nathaniel on Twitter. Check out RWN EP #278 — Idriss Déby & Chaditude Music interlude by Brendon Anderegg. Check out music from his group Mountains here. item.title: Radio War Nerd EP 435 — ISKP's Friends in US-Occupied Afghanistan, feat. Rob Ashlar
item.itunes:subtitle: Co-hosts Gary Brecher & Mark Ames
item.itunes:summary: Guest: Rob Ashlar Recorded: March 28, 2024 To make sense of the ISKP (Islamic State-Khorasan Province) attacks in Moscow last week, and Iran earlier this year, we dive into its murky origins during the US occupation in Afghanistan and the terrorist group's remarkably friendly relations with occupied Afghanistan's security agency, the National Directorate for Security (NDS), which was created and run by the CIA. Key acronyms & names for this episode:-TTP (Tehrik e Taliban Pakistan): Pakistan Taliban, remnants form early ISKP in Nangarhar Province-ISKP (Islamic State in Khorasan Province)-NDS (National Directorate for Security): Occupied Afghanistan's CIA-run intelligence agency-Amrullah Saleh: Longtime head of NDS-Mangal Bagh/ Lashkar e Islam: Large ISKP affiliate in Nangarhar with documented NDS backing-ANA (Afghan National Army), ANSF (Afghan National Security Forces): US-occupied Afghan military-Shahab al Muhajir (aka Sanaullah Ghafari): ISKP's emir, from Kabul, possible foreigner or Tajik-Abdul Manan: Extremist Taliban who broke away in 2015, year ISKP formed, allied with ISKP, documented links to US-occupied Afghanistan regime-AAN (Afghanistan Analysts Network): reliable analysis on Afghanistan Read Rob Ashlar's articles in Cosmonaut, here and here. Follow Rob on Twitter. Total time: 1:31:20 Direct link to this episode's mp3 here * Subscribe to Radio War Nerd at patreon.com/radiowarnerd Sound production by Telescope Audio Check out the Radio War Nerd Merch store here! item.itunes:subtitle: Co-hosts Gary Brecher & Mark Ames
item.itunes:summary: Recorded: May 26, 2023 Every GOP contender for president in 2024 has a plan to invade Mexico upon taking office, and the good news is it's been done before so we don't have to guess how stupidly badly it will go. This episode the Nerd & Ames look back at Pancho Villa's raid on a small New Mexico town — a marketing & recruiting event that went a li'l haywire — and what happened when Woodrow Wilson made another of his trademark disastrous decisions, sending the US military into Mexico to chase Villa down. First — we chat about bad Italian-meets-Dada... At 12:15 — we break down the cream of the GOPnik crop's big plans for invading Mexico in 2024... At 36:24 — we tell the story of Pancho Villa, his rise & fall, his attempted comeback using a provocative raid on a US border town, which properly provoked Woodrow Wilson into ordering the US military to invade (but not really invade, but yeah to invade) Mexico in 1916, and you can guess how brilliantly that went. item.itunes:summary: Guest: Nelson Denis, writer & filmmaker  Recorded: September 10, 2019 "Alvaro, are we invisible?"—Puerto Rico's remarkable independence leader Pedro Albizu Campos said this to one of his comrades during the failed 1950 rebellion against US rule. For some strange reason, Americans know more about historical crimes committed by our foreign adversaries than we do about the the appalling catalogue of crimes committed against America's own territorial colony: Puerto Rico. Thankfully, we have guest Nelson Denis to slap us awake, with his unforgettable book "War Against All Puerto Ricans: Revolution and Terror in America's Colony". It's a grim story of massacres, colonial exploitation, gruesome experiments and subjugation—but it has some of the most amazing characters, and they're real, all too real: from Nationalist leader Pedro Albizu Campos and Vidal Santiago Díaz — the barber who fought off an army from inside his barber salon . . . to sleazy villains like the Mengele-esque Dr. Cornelius Rhoads, and Luis Munoz Marin. We had some sound issues this episode, so bear with us. Buy Nelson Denis' book "War Against All Puerto Ricans: Revolution and Terror in America's Colony".

item.title: Radio War Nerd EP176 — The Hundred Years War (Part II)
item.itunes:subtitle: Co-hosts Gary Brecher & Mark Ames
item.itunes:summary: Guest: "Annibale" Recorded: April 5, 2019 We continue the story of the Hundred Years War. In Part I, we brought the war up to the 1340s after England's crushing defeat of the French navy at Sluys, followed up by the English army's devastating invasion of the French interior — Edward III's chevauchée, or plunder & mass murder raids — culminating at the battle of Crécy. This episode, Annibale takes us from the devastating Black Plague, which hit France hardest, wiping out roughly half of the population in a matter of a few years, and its effects on the Hundred Years War. After the Plague settles down, England gets its war on France again, unleashing an even more devastating chevauchée on the French countryside in the 1350s & capture French King John II . . . Annibale takes us through the rise of Charles V, the 28-year truce, & the resumption of the war with Henry IV's invasion of France. We end Part II with Henry V's victory at Agincourt . . . At 2:16:00 War Nerd & Ames discuss Max Blumenthal's new book controversy - Max will be our guest in the next episode . . . post-Russiagate lunacy . . .

item.itunes:subtitle: Co-hosts Gary Brecher & Mark Ames
item.itunes:summary: Recorded: March 29, 2019 First, the War Nerd and Ames discuss the long-anticipated collapse of the Russiagate conspiracy hysteria — and with it, whatever's left of the established media and political class's credibility. It's a giant silver platter gift for Trump 2020's campaign. But as Ames argues, it's more than just a question of narratives and credibility, as the last American freak-out over Russian "active measures" was used to justify a massive domestic spying and political harassment campaign . . .  At 37:00 — we're joined by popular Radio War Nerd guest "Annibale" to walk us through the Hundred Years War — roughly 1337-1453, depending on who you ask — one of the most catastrophic wars in history that depopulated entire swathes of Europe . . . We know so little about the Hundred Years War, though it's arguably the narrative basis for George RR Martin's "Game Of Thrones". To help us understand this war, Annibale first helps us to understand the world of the Middle Ages, weeding out the Enlightenment-era myths that persist through today. We learn about local economies, societies, politics, and military technologies and tactics of the time, and how they began to change with the war.  "Annibale" is an Italian fellow war nerd. He was a RWN guest for our 3-part "Years Of Lead" series on Italy in the Cold War (episodes 135, 136, 139); as well as episode #131 on the Italian Resistance in WWII, and episode #134, an introduction to Italy's postwar "Years Of Lead" period.

item.title: Radio War Nerd EP167—"False Flags" from Mukden to Maidan + Captain Alatriste
item.itunes:subtitle: Co-hosts Gary Brecher & Mark Ames
item.itunes:summary: Guest: Dr. Ivan Katchanovski, professor of political science at U. Ottawa  Recorded: January 30, 2019 As Trump's regime-change operation in Venezuela gathers momentum, we take a look at the sort of "false flag" operations in the past that have triggered interventions and regime-change. From the Mukden Incident in 1931, a Japanese Imperial Army false flag train bombing used as the pretext for Japan's invasion of Manchuria — to the mysterious sniper killings precipitating the 2002 US-backed coup against Hugo Chavez in Venezuela, false flags do really happen, even if the concept has been flogged to death by professional paranoiacs like Alex Jones. For this episode, we talk to Dr. Ivan Katchanovski, the Ukrainian born scholar who has been analyzing inconsistencies in the 2014 Maidan massacre in Ukraine, when 49 people were killed in events leading up to Yanukovych's overthrow. At 2:21:00 the War Nerd talks about the "Alatriste" series of historical novels by Spanish author Arturo Pérez- Reverte that take place during Spain's "Golden Age" in the early 17th C. The novels covered: Captain Alatriste, Purity of Blood, The Sun Over Breda. Read Dr Katchanovski's reports on the Maidan massacre; buy his books here and here; follow him on Facebook and Twitter. item.title: Radio War Nerd EP161—Populism & "populism"
item.itunes:subtitle: Co-hosts Gary Brecher & Mark Ames
item.itunes:summary: Recorded: December 11, 2018 Guest: Dr. Christopher Phelps, associate professor U. Nottingham & author  The word "populism" gets thrown around a lot today in the mainstream press, usually meant as a pejorative to describe far-right reactionary, anti-democratic politics that threaten the so-called "liberal order." But "populism" is just a synonym for "democracy" — "of the people" — and it has a concrete historical meaning that's completely at odds with the current abused meaning of the word. The War Nerd talks to intellectual historian Christopher Phelps about the original meaning of "Populism" in the United States at the end of the 19th C., and we try to sort out myths from facts, and what the word means today in Europe and in the official US media. Throughout the discussion, we reference Lawrence Goodwyn's great book: "The Populist Moment".   At 1:43:00 — Ames & the War Nerd discuss a few of the larger-than-life Populists, France's "yellow vests" movement . . . And then briefly look at current war news: ISIS battling US-backed SDF in its last stronghold in Syria, along Iraq border . . . Al Qaeda jihadis take main Syria road in Idlib, against Turkey-Russia peace agreement . . . Qatari emir wisely avoids GCC summit . . . Qatar has played soft-power propaganda game brilliantly, gotten away with murder . . . Read Christopher Phelps' books Radicals In America: The U.S. Left since the Second World War and Young Sidney Hook: Marxist and Pragmatist. Check out his articles in The Nationand Jacobin.

item.itunes:summary: Guests: Harun Maruf & Dan Joseph, authors & journalists  Recorded: November 27, 2018 The War Nerd talks to the authors of "Inside Al-Shabaab: The Secret History of Al Qaeda's Most Powerful Ally", an excellent and well-reported book on Somalia's wars with the deadly and remarkably innovative jihadi insurgents. item.title: Radio War Nerd EP157—The Meuse-Argonne Offensive, 1918
item.itunes:subtitle: Co-hosts Gary Brecher & Mark Ames
item.itunes:summary: Recorded November 15, 2018 To mark the 100th anniversary of the War To End All Wars, the War Nerd and Ames discuss the American military's biggest contribution to the Entente victory: the Meuse-Argonne offensive, launched in the last six weeks of the war. Turns it this was the largest and deadliest battle in US military history — 26,000 killed, nearly 100,000 wounded — featuring the most epic traffic jams in American history (see photo above), led by a gaggle of psychopathic dumb-as-nails US officers. Despite professing to love war so much, hardly any Americans even know about their military's biggest battle ever. And for good reason, as we learn. It did not go very well. And all that death and embarrassment didn't even matter much anyway—the Meuse-Argonne wasn't all that important compared to the Entente's other major battlefronts during the Hundred Days Offensive that ended the war. Afterwards at 2:02:00 — the War Nerd briefly talks about World War One poetry, the dividing moment between pro-war verse and the sort of antiwar verse that's been the rule ever since . . . Also, Afghanistan going from awful to awfuler . . .

We start the episode off with a bunch of questions we've been wanting to ask Annibale  —then pick up around the time of Aldo Moro's mysterious kidnapping-murder by the Red Brigades, through the final self-destructive violence of Italy's radical revolutionary leftists. Annibale then tells us about the darkest  mystery in that era—the Ustica crash, when an Italian passenger plane was shot down by a missile killing everyone aboard, and the deadly coverups that followed the Ustica crash to this day. And there's plenty of strange Italian grotesque, like the famous  child actor-turned-neofascist terrorist, Valerio Fioravanti, implicated in the Bologna massacre. A very, very strange and dark finale to a strange and dark period that we knew far too little about. . . .

item.itunes:subtitle: Co-hosts Gary Brecher & Mark Ames
item.itunes:summary: Guest: Yasha Levine, author & journalist  The War Nerd talks to investigative journalist Yasha Levine about his controversial new book, "Surveillance Valley" about the inseparable relationship between the Internet industry and US military-intelligence. Levine dives deep into the origins of the Internet, designed by Pentagon researchers to create an all-seeing counterinsurgency weapon in wars abroad, and against protest movements home in the USA. Fifty years ago, student radicals protested the early Internet as a Big Brother weapon of oppression; today, young "radicals" in the Internet Freedom movement promote this Pentagon weapon as a force for liberation and revolution against the same Big Brother state. Levine explains how these paradoxes came to be—and why Snowden's revelations about government spying on the Internet revealed not a bug in the system that can be "fixed", but rather the whole purpose of the Internet system from the start. Grim, hopeless & fascinating.  Buy Yasha Levine's book "Surveillance Valley: The Secret Military History of the Internet" and check out his book tour!

item.title: Radio War Nerd EP111—The Battle of Lepanto
item.itunes:subtitle: Co-hosts Gary Brecher & Mark Ames
item.itunes:summary: The War Nerd brings some belated justice to long-maligned southern Europeans for their forgotten heroic battles against the fearsome Ottoman Empire war machine. We look at some of the major Ottoman-Hapsburg battles of the mid-late 16th c. with a special focus on one of the most incredible naval battles in history: The Battle of Lepanto. If we were to see the North/South divide in Europe from a perspective of something like historical justice, all this talk about the North supporting the lazy South and East would be reversed. There's a reason British and French fleets were free to sail for easier, more lucrative conquests: because the people of the Eastern Mediterranean fought through centuries of raiding, enslavement, pillage, and sheer terror to hold the great Ottoman Empire at bay. Think of those EU fees as reparations. At 1:34:00 the Nerd and Ames discuss today's war news: the latest North Korea ICBM; Sinai mosque attack that killed over 300; Israel military think-tank talking up alliance with Islamic State, again; Saudis whipping up anti-Iran war fever; weird "coup" in breakaway pro-Russian Luhansk People's Republic in eastern Ukraine; Chechen IS commander Akhmed Chatayev killed in Georgia...

item.title: Radio War Nerd EP110—Disinformation Warfare
item.itunes:subtitle: Co-hosts Gary Brecher & Mark Ames
item.itunes:summary: Panic over "Russian disinformation" has dominated much of the DC Establishment discourse, especially since Trump's shock election victory. item.title: Radio War Nerd EP103—1857 Indian Rebellion
item.itunes:subtitle: Co-hosts Gary Brecher & Mark Ames
item.itunes:summary: Guest: Aditya Velivelli For over a century the 1857 Indian uprising was called "The Sepoy Mutiny", framed as a British tragedy in which Englishmen and women senselessly murdered by crazed Indian barbarians. But like so many crimes of the British Empire, the truth is starting to come out. To Indians, it's known as "The First War of Independence" which it rightly was, a nationwide uprising against the British East India Company's brutal colonial rule. The War Nerd discusses the 1857 rebellion with Hyderabad-born fellow war nerd Aditya Velivelli—the BEIC's cruel extractive rule, the tens of millions of Indians killed in artificial famines caused by British reshaping of India's political economy, and the course of battles in 1857-9, that ended with the British state officially taking over direct rule from the private East India Company.

item.title: Radio War Nerd EP102—Russian Civil War + Remembering Stanislav Petrov
item.itunes:subtitle: Co-hosts Gary Brecher & Mark Ames
item.itunes:summary: Guest: Alex Zaitchik, journalist & author In this two-part episode, first the War Nerd talks to journalist and former eXile colleague Alex Zaichik—just back from the oil-poisoned jungles of Peru—about his evening with Stanislav Petrov, "the man who saved the world" from nuclear holocaust in 1983, who just died this week. At 40:08 we discuss The Committee to Investigate Russia, the bazillionth liberal-neocon-CIA project, this one headed up by Rob "Meathead" Reiner, to resurrect Cold War fever. At 1:04:26 we begin our segment on the Russian Civil War, a huge topic about a very alien (and much romanticized) world. The War Nerd gives both an overview of the various phases of battle & some of the major figures. Later we dive deeper into some of the incredible episodes of the war, such as the peasant rebellions and the extraordinary anarchist partisan leader Nestor Makhno. The War Nerd ends with a list of his favorite Russian Civil War novels and writers...

We look into the brutal British legacy in Burma (Myanmar), the history of ethnic tensions in the part of the Empire where today Rakhine death squads are expelling Rohingya, the mirror Chittagong Hills Tract conflict story ignored by our media, and the CIA-backed Chinese Nationalist KMT army that spent years in northeast Burma running a heroin narco-state ... Afterwards, the War Nerd and Ames take more RWN subscriber call-in questions... item.title: Radio War Nerd EP96—Sino-India War of 1962
item.itunes:subtitle: Co-hosts Gary Brecher & Mark Ames
item.itunes:summary: Guest: Aditya Velivelli  China and India have been trading hot words and menacing editorials this summer over a border dispute in Bhutan, where both Chinese and Indian forces have crossed borders and made threats. The roots of this go back to the little-known 1962 Sino-India War, which ended in humiliating defeat for Nehru. Fellow war nerd Aditya Velivelli, originally from Hyderabad, walks us through events in the 1950s between India and China, and the disastrous finalé in the 1962 war, which was fought on two vastly different border fronts: In India's far northeast frontier border with Tibet, and in the disputed Kashmir region in India's far northwest, in the Aksai Chin plateau. Some useful maps: 1. Battlefronts in 1962 war: Kashmir region in NW (Aksai Chin); Arunachal Pradesh state in NE ("Southern Tibet" acc to China). 2. Close-up map of NW theater in Kashmir. Aksai Chin taken by China, highway linking Tibet with Xinjiang running through Aksai Chin. 3. Closeup map of NE theater in India's Arunachar Pradesh state (called "North East Frontier Area" or NEFA, in 1962). Worst battles took place in far west corner of Arunachar Pradesh, ie Bhutan's northeast edge. 4. 4. Map of 2017 standoff in "tri-junction" area in Bhutan's far northwest Total time: 2:14:10 Suggested reading:  "Himalayan Blunder" by JP Dalvi  "India and the China Crisis" by Steven A Hoffman  "1962: The War That Wasn't" by Shiv Kunal Verma

Tajikistan is the poorest of the USSR's five Central Asian republics, and the only one dominated by ethnic Persian speakers rather than Turkic. Because it borders Afghanistan, the wars there since the Soviet invasion in 1979 through today impact Tajikistan, and visa-versa.  Afterwards, Brecher & Ames discuss the suspected jihadi stabbing in Hamburg; the bizarre CIA-backed Cuban civil war inside the Congo civil wars in the 1960s; Saudi Arabia's quiet war on its Shia population... item.itunes:summary: Guest: Carl Zha The War Nerd brings back our popular west coast wn guest Carl Zha to talk about the great Chinese war epic, Romance of the Three Kingdoms — the 14th century novel by Luo Guanzhong, and said to be one of Mao's favorite novels during his guerrilla years. The novel tells the story of chaos, divisions and betrayals in the late Han Empire era in the second and third centuries AD — and it's been the basis for countless retellings, online games, graphic comix and more. Carl talks about the context, history, and stories behind the three main characters and their rival kingdoms, and how they fit into Chinese history and politics. . . . Afterwards, the War Nerd and Ames — both at various stages of lung fluid sickness — talk about a New Republic article attacking Radio War Nerd as part of a "dirtbag left" movement, and the War Nerd's response . . .
